feedback_items.title: SUDS Monitoring During Imaginal Exposure
feedback_items.summary: Repeated SUDS monitoring during imaginal exposure.
feedback_items.observation: The therapist elicits SUDS ratings repeatedly during the imaginal exposure.

evidence.text: Tear gas exposure: SUDS = "80. Maybe higher."
After being pushed toward the police van: SUDS = "95."
After release and leaving the station: SUDS = "75."

feedback_items.title: Engagement with Internal Experience
feedback_items.summary: Adequate engagement with internal experience during exposure.
feedback_items.observation: The therapist consistently prompts physiological, emotional, and cognitive experience and provides reinforcing statements during imaginal recounting.

evidence.text: Reinforcement: "You're doing well," "You're doing great," "You've done really well."
Physiology prompts: "What are you feeling in your body?" and "What's happening in your body?"
Cognitive prompt: "Stay with it. What are you thinking?"
Emotion prompts: "What are you feeling now?" and "Stay with those thoughts. What happens next?"

feedback_items.evaluation: These behaviors are consistent with PE expectations for maintaining engagement during imaginal exposure.

feedback_items.title: Post-Exposure Processing
feedback_items.observation: Following imaginal exposure, the therapist validates the client's experience and proceeds to session closure without an explicit processing segment.

evidence.text: After the client reports feeling "broken," the therapist validates and orients the client back to the room.
After the client later reports feeling "stronger for having faced this," the therapist initiates end-of-session breathing and closure.

feedback_items.evaluation: The transition to closure is appropriate but leaves limited space for explicit meaning-making.
feedback_items.suggestion: Add a brief processing segment after exposure (for example, what stood out most or how the client is interpreting the experience) to support learning consolidation.
